segments.text: This is an interview with Robert E. Kirk by George S. West on April 30, 1989, at Point Blank, Texas, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I am going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection and the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, it is.
Let's start with some background questions first, such as your date and place of birth.
August 30, 1937, in Rensselaer, Indiana.
What kind of education did you receive before entering the service?
I completed my sophomore year in high school and then I quit high school and joined the Army.
While I was in the Army, I finished my high school education in GED while I was in Germany.
What did you do before Vietnam?
Well, that would be a student and then I joined the Army
I guess I'd been in the Army almost 10 years before I went to Vietnam.
Did you know much about the war before you went to Vietnam?
Just what I read in the newspapers and while I was in Germany I was in the intelligence section and we got periodic reports from Vietnam.
But they were classified.
Was any training you received useful?
just my basic training.
Why did you enlist in the service?
I guess my basic reason was I just wanted to serve the country.
When and where did you serve?
I think it's pretty lengthy.
I started out for my basic training

Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri in 1954, and I went to Aberdeen, Maryland, and took my second English, the basic, which was in the Ordnance Corps, in ammunition, storage, handling, renovation, and EOD work.
Upon completion of basic training, I went to Germany, wound up in the Monterey Battalion as an ammo specialist,
And within a year, I decided to become a mechanic.
I went to mechanic school and continued being a mechanic for the next four years.
Then I got out of the Army briefly in 1958.
Stayed out 11 months.
While I was out, I worked as a mechanic.
Then I went back in the military and into the Military Police Corps.
Went to military police school in Fort
Fort Gordon, Georgia.
Upon completion of military police school, I was reassigned to Korea, the 7th Infantry Division, and Camp Kaiser.
I stayed there three years, and two and a half years of that three years, I was a military police investigator.
Upon completion of my Korean tour, I was reassigned to Fort Chaffee, Arkansas,
at the 66th Military Police Company.
And through the course of commotions and whatnot, they had to change my MLS to infantry.
So I was reassigned to a 45th Infantry Battalion in Fort Chappie.
However, we only were activated three months before they closed Fort Chappie.
Then I was reassigned to Fort Benning to the Ranger Department as an instructor.
Stayed there about eight months, I believe, and then I was reassigned back to Germany.
Wound up in a tank battalion, the 2nd Battalion, 68th Armored, in Baumholder, Germany.

That was supposed to have been a three-year tour, but I was curtailed from that assignment three months early to come back to Fort Riley, Kansas, to activate the 9th Infantry Division and go to Vietnam.
So approximately eight or nine months after I was in Fort Plough, we packed up as an entire division and went to Vietnam.
Took us about 27 days to get there by ship.
And I spent a year in Vietnam, and I came back to the States, Fort Polk, Louisiana, to training units.
Stayed in the States one year.
Back to Vietnam for another year.
Back to Fort Polk for nearly 18 months, I believe.
Then I went back to Korea again.
Stayed in Korea a year again.
Back to the States, to Fort Polk a third time, to 55th and 1st and Old Trent Police Company.
Stayed there until I retired.
in August of 1975.
What were, what was your rank and what were your duties in Vietnam?
My first time in Vietnam I was a sergeant first class, platoon sergeant, and of course as that rank I was a platoon sergeant.
But after our first engagement with the enemy
I became a platoon leader, and for the next 11 months I worked as a platoon leader, which is normal rank as a lieutenant.
The second time in Vietnam, I went over, my rank was first sergeant, but my duty assignment was sergeant major in the 24th Spatial Tactical Zone, which is a Vietnamese unit under MACV.
What was everyday life like?
Well, everyday life was pretty miserable.
We were in the boondocks more than we were anywhere else.
And we were always hot, wet, and muddy.
We very rarely saw any dry land.
We were always in the rice paddies.
If we saw one that was dry, we thought we were in heaven.
How did you and your unit try to fight the war?
Well, we tried to fight war as if you're normally trained.
I mean, we know what our function is, and we go out on our missions.
We try to conduct it the way we knew it was supposed to be conducted.
There were times they sent us out, and they sent us to a so-called free-fire zone that anything that moves, you shoot at.
And there's other times they tell you, well, this is a no-fire zone, meaning that if you receive fire, you can't return fire.
To me, that's not the way to fight a war.
And you can't see the enemy.
They see you, and they know the terrain, and we don't.
I don't think we were allowed to fight the war.
What kind of operations were you involved in?
Were they mainly successes or failures?
Well, that's a difficult question.
We were foot infantry.
We didn't have any vehicles.
And we were attached to the Navy and we were rivering force.
So the Navy pretty much took us where we were going and eventually picked us up and brought us back.
But if we couldn't go by water, we could go by air helicopter.
And if we couldn't go those two ways, we just walked.
We went on all kinds of combat operations.
We searched and destroyed routine patrol.
We were searching out for the enemy.
Maybe we find them, maybe we don't.
More often than not, we didn't.
And we'd be used as blocking forces for another unit that was making a sweep somewhere.
As far as success,
I don't know how you would measure success.
When we engage the enemy, we always seem to inflict more damage to them than they did us.
Those times we could find evidence after the battle, but more often than not, after the battle, you search the area, we couldn't find any of them.
We'd find blood, but we didn't find any bodies for the most part.
So, as far as being successful,
I wouldn't really have any idea.
Are there any specific missions that you remember that stand out in your mind?
Oh yes, there's a couple that stand out in my mind.

I don't remember the exact dates and some of the places, but there was in the Canaan area that was pretty well infested with a combination of VC and VA. Any time we went up in there, we wound up against the
a pretty large force.
Fortunately for us, our force was always larger than theirs.
We'd take a few cagulets, but like I say, very rarely did we find the enemy bodies.
And then there were some times we'd go through the rice paddies, and it may be knee-deep in water, and we'd stumble sometimes, and all of a sudden some bodies would float to the top.
But we thought most of those were
killed by either artillery fire or B-52 strike that just happened to fly away.
I don't think we, as such, inflicted the casualties.
We just happened to stumble across them.
But then there was one major battle where we were fighting, I think it was 264th VC Regiment, and I believe it was in May of 67, where when we
finally swept the area, we found it.
And whatever position they happened to be in when they crawled in the bunkers, that's how we found them.
But there was also a combination of B-52 Arclight the night before we went in.
The Arclight probably created the most casualties.
But a few weeks later we captured a courier

that had some documents on to him from the commander of that unit, explaining that they'd practically been wiped out, that they didn't even have enough people to think about reorganizing, and he needed immediate replacements.
Well, that was approximately May.
The following September, December the 17th, exactly, we were

sent on a mission somewhere in the central delta area we were going by by boat and we were supposed to go to this location and find a large cache of enemy weapons and we were supposed to beach at 7 30 in the morning and make a sweep approximately 8 000 meters north and we were found
However, 7 o'clock that morning, we ran through an ambush from both sides of the river.
And there was some pretty heavy fighting on that one.
My platoon was the lead boat.
The CO happened to be on the boat with me.
And we went through the ambush site and made it to our beaching site and went ashore.
Though we didn't get more than 200 yards inside, we couldn't advance any more.
back to both my point and pinned down and wounded.
And the battalion commander was upstairs in the helicopter and he could see what was going on.
And he told us to get back on our boat and rejoin the battalion.
It seems the rest of the boats, when we hit that ambush, they backed up and beached a safe distance from the ambush site.
So we finally got back on our boats
Went back through that ambush again.
Didn't take any more casualties at that time.
And we rejoined the battalion a couple miles upstream and started evacuating the wounded.
That day we had 101 casualties, 99 wounded and two killed.
One soldier and one sailor were killed, and then the wounded was a combination of both.
Each one of our boats had, I believe it was eight sails on it, and the rest of us were on it.
After we evacuated all our wounded, we went back through that ambush again.
But this time, we just met sporadic fire in the ambush site.
The enemy had used that time interval to withdraw somewhat.
But it still took us approximately eight hours to go a couple thousand meters for the sporadic fire.
We never did find a body.
And we did not find a weapons cache.
Which leads me to believe that the information that the intelligence was working on initially was planted information that they knew we were coming.
But they ambushed us 30 minutes before we were to land it.
Fortunately for us, our boats were on the plane.
Then there was another one.
I don't remember if it was October or November 67.
Somewhere in the Delta.
We were already on an operation.
We didn't find anything.
And then the CO received a radio transmission to pack up
and move about 10 clicks off to the west with a separate mission.
Well, the choppers came in and we only had enough choppers to take two platoons.
So the first and third platoon left and the CO went with them.
And before he left, he told me, well, the choppers will come back and get us.
But if they're not back within 30 minutes for us to walk over to where they were.
so that while they're gone, I look among them and I pick out a route to get there the quickest and easiest, just in case those choppers didn't come back.
The distance from where I was to where the SEAL and the rest of the company eventually lined up was out of our radio limitation, so I couldn't hear what was going on over there.

and it but i did find out over the radio that our choppers was diverted to another operation so we were about to saddle up and move out to marry up with the rest of the company and all of a sudden some more choppers came in from some place i don't know who they belong to but it was obvious they were us because they landed and picked us up and took us
As we're coming in, all hell broke loose, and there was bullets flying everywhere, and we're still in the air.
And as we're coming down, my lead helicopter was hit and crashed into the ground.
Intact, fortunately, with everybody on it.
I was in the second chopper.
And we dived out of those helicopters,
I happened to land right near the CO, and he was telling me that he was trying to wave us off.
We were too busy to notice him.
Didn't see him trying to wave us off.
We did not know there was a hot LZ.
And because of all this firing going on, pretty well occupied, so I didn't really know what was going on around.
And all these helicopters taking back off,
Out of the clear blue sky come a medivac helicopter and managed to get all the casualties off that first helicopter.
But I thought, sure, he was going to crash into the helicopter because all of them trying to rise and he's down there and then he's trying to rise and he was losing control.
But he managed to maintain control of that medivac and got out of there safely.
And the SEAL got his tail member because we hadn't even called in the medivac.
And he got his tail number so we could eventually find out who he was.
And we eventually got that chopper pilot's distinguished line across.
Well, after the choppers were all gone, of course, we still got that disabled chopper there.
And the SEAL was explaining to me what we got.
Well, we called in some helicopter gunships, and eventually the Air Force came in and
give us some supporting fire.
And the helicopter pilot was telling us we were in a horseshoe ambush and told us the limits of it.
And he was telling us about all the bodies that they could see laying around there.
Now the CO wanted me to send a patrol off to within my right flank forward, skirting the ambush to see what we could do about trying to outflank them.
So I sent one of my squads, one of my best squad leaders, out to plank that ambush and see what we could do, but they didn't get very far before they told us that they couldn't go any further.
So the SEAL told me to bring them back.
I brought them back.
While all this was going on, there was this huge tree in front of us, and the SEAL already figured out there was a machine gun
in placement at the base of that tree that had gotten five men out of the first team.
And I don't know why, but I was looking at the top of that tree, and I saw two black objects.
But I didn't know what they were.
But one of them appeared to be moving, getting higher.
And then he comes back, a little bit closer to that other one.
And at first I thought it was just my eyes playing tricks on me, but I was certain that it was moving.
So I asked the CO what to say.
He said, look up there in that tree and tell me if one of those black blobs isn't moving.
And he looked up there and he, by the way, the owner.
So I pointed my rifle up there and I pulled off around.
It was obvious that that M16 was ineffective.
We're up there.
too far away, and all the brush in the tree.
So I went over to that downed helicopter, because I know there's two machine guns there, and I was debating whether to get in behind that one machine gun and fire at that thing in the tree.
And I got to think, well, no.
The grass is high enough around here, the other can't see me.
But they could damn sure see that helicopter.
And they knew where those machine guns were on that chopper.
Had to commit suicide to get behind that gun.
But I saw that M14 strapped to the pilot's seat.
It had two magazines in it, taped together.
So I took the M14 out, and it was filthy.
I couldn't get the bolt open.
I had to put it on the ground and open it with my foot.
And I went back with the tail boom of the helicopter, and I laid my rifle over the tail boom.
But that first round wouldn't go off.
So I ejected that, put a second round in the chamber.
And I fired at that blob that I saw moving, but I missed.
So I fired the second round.
And all of a sudden, here comes this bird flying out of the ground, out of the tree, landing on the ground on his head.
It was an enemy soldier.
About that time, all kinds of bullets started hitting the tail boom of that helicopter.
I decided that's not the place to be.
And as I'm about to move out, I heard somebody holler.
And it was one of our men from the 3rd platoon.
He was a little ways in front of that helicopter.
And I hollered at him to find out where he was, and he told me he was wounded.
So I kind of crawled over to where he was and helped him back over to the
company headquarters.
And then the CO decided to call artillery in.
And he gave the artillery people their accordance, told them how far ahead to fire the rounds.
And artillery brought in some smoke.
And by the time they finished, there was no tree standing there.
Just a stump and a bunch of brush around.
And it was getting dark.
So we were told we had to stay and guard that helicopter.
So we set up a perimeter defense.
In the process of setting up a perimeter defense, that's when I realized I only had about half of my people.
And we started looking around for the other half.
Both my machine gun crews were gone.
And because it was getting dark, I suggested to the CO
We don't search for them anymore.
Because everybody will be scared.
And there's no shooter or anything that moves.
So wherever they are, we just leave them there.
And in the morning, we'll go out where people can see each other and we'll start searching for them.
He agreed with me.
But I assumed they were on the ground somewhere.
The next morning,
We start popping our heads up above the dikes.
We're not receiving any fire.
So we assume the enemy had withdrawn.
So the SEAL calls that brigade to get a Chinook to come in and pull that helicopter out.
And we start searching for my missing troops.
And we didn't find them.
So he called base camp.
And sure enough, they were all back at base camp.
It seemed that the last three choppers in my group that brought us in couldn't get close enough to the ground to disgorge my troops.
And some of them became casualties, too, while they were still in the air.
So, I don't have any machine guns, and I only have half my platoon.
And we've got to carry on with the mission.
So I went up to that helicopter before the Chinook got there, and I took the two machine guns off of it.
Unfortunately, the gunners had left the bipods on them.
Half of them take the bipods off.
And when the Chinook came in, I told the crew chief to let the commander of that helicopter know that I have the weapons off that chopper.
And when we finish with this mission and get back to base camp, we'll see if they get the weapons back.
But I need the weapons.
So after they took the Huey off, they wanted a body count of the enemy's casualties.
So we started searching the area for enemy casualties.
Now we already know what the gunship pilot was telling us about bodies laying everywhere.
And the CO and I both saw that clown come flying out of that tree.
But of course, he's probably buried underneath all that bush, and we're not about to pull it up and look for one stupid body.
But in the process of searching for bodies, we did not find one.
And I think we had nine or ten killed, and I don't remember how many wounded.
And we did not find one single body.
And Brigade called the SEAL and wanted a body count.
He told me, he said, I can't find him.
He said, you better come up with a body count.
So the SEAL and I, we were pretty close.
And she said, well, what do you think, Bob?
I said, well, those cops were telling me that the body's all over the place.
I think it'd be safe to say we got 10.
We know we lost 10.
He said, that sounds like a good figure.
So he told them ten.
And they come on the air and they chewed him out.
With all that ordnance you've expended out there, you can only come up with ten, you better come up with a better figure.
The SEAL refused to raise the figure.
Well, when they finally wrote up the operation, they put something like a hundred and
a hundred and some enemy casualties, and we didn't even find one.
I don't believe any figures from Vietnam are friendly or enemy.
In fact, in my personal opinion, if you tallied up all the casualties we were supposed to have inflicted on the enemy in the early 60s, I'd like to know who in the world we were fighting.
I think we should have wiped out the whole male population.
And there were several other battles, but they didn't really amount to nothing.
We got a bunch of unit declarations for our operations.
I think that's so much junk to sell.
Did you see many changes during your tours regarding the missions?
Regarding what missions you were sent on?
The missions you were sent on, such as more search and destroy?
Well, we were sent on probably more search and destroys than anything else.
Well, there was a couple times we'd be on search and destroy and we'd find evidence of enemy activity.
Like we'd find some places where they were scrounging up C-ration cans and there was all kinds of shrapnel around.
It was obvious that they were making movie traps out of old C-ration cans.
In fact, a couple of my people
lost a foot or something to a sea ration can of peaches.
And when we find stuff like that, we destroyed the dwelling that all that stuff was in.
One time, we set fire to a couple of haystacks because they were in our way for an operation.
And it was getting dark.
Those haystacks, they were lighting up the area pretty well.
We could see what was going on out there.
But all of a sudden, there was an explosion.
Of course, that alerted everybody.
We started looking at where the hell that explosion was coming from.
And all of a sudden, two of those haystacks started blowing up.
They kept blowing up all night long.
There was all kinds of ammunition stored in those haystacks.
And then there was some other times that
They sent us on a search and destroy mission, and they told us to destroy anything we came upon.
And when we come upon them, a series of weapons, we destroy them.
That's what our orders were.
And those orders originally supposedly came from the Vietnamese government, that anybody in that area is enemy or enemy sympathizer.
There was one village
We'd come in through, not on a search and destroy operation.
We were there to guard that village so that they could safely vote without any interference from any enemy antagonists.
And it was daytime, so I gave my people 75% off and 25% alert.
We didn't expect anything to happen during the daytime.
And I was half asleep, and I heard some yelling.
It sounded like a little kid hollering.
So I go to where I hear the noise coming from, and there's a couple of my troops standing there, and they've got this little kid by his feet, upside down, dunking him in this big old pond.
I walk up there, and I make them stop, and what the hell do you think you're doing?
Then they told me that he stole seven grenades,
He got caught in the act of stealing the last one.
Then I said, well, carry on until we find those grenades.
So eventually, he showed us where the grenades were stashed.
And of course, we kept him in prison for the remainder of the day and night.
We wanted to turn him over to the White Mice National Police the next day.
And he couldn't have been more than eight or nine.
But they can kill you just as well as a grown man can.
But I had a couple of engineers, mine sweeping team, that we didn't need.
And I assigned them to keep an eye on this little kid.
I should have assigned one of my own troops, but I assigned those people.
And early in the morning, that little kid escaped.
And I'll tell you, you never saw anybody run so fast across those rice paddies.
He got away.
But he was only somewhere between seven and nine years old.
And we ran into a couple of females that just as soon as you shoot you, they look at you.
We wound up having to kill two of them.
We had white mice with us on a couple of operations.
We stumbled over ten
enemy that was hidden in a hole underneath a piece of sheet steel.
And they finally got unnerved, I guess, and took off.
And we caught them.
And these white mice, each one on that Thompson .45 submachine gun, I thought they were going to blow all of them away.
And they had them laying flat on the ground in the barrel of that submachine gun, sticking right in its forehead, jabbering their gibberish.
I don't know what all that enemy crew told him, but I mean to tell you, he was doing some talking.
Probably told them a lot more than what they really asked for.
And I expected them to blow them away anyhow.
To my knowledge, they evacuated the rear after that.
I don't know what happened to them.
Did you notice any changes of troop morale?
No.
My first time over there,

we had pretty good morale although there was times we wondered what in the world we're doing here i mean they send us out and won't let us do anything or well we go out there and we walk and walk and walk and walk and jump to see a cotton picking vine and it got kind of frustrating we thought we were there to fight a war but we didn't really have that much
actual combat going on.
We'd be out there maybe two weeks and not see or hear a cotton picket sign.
Then another time he'd go out and all hell breaks loose.
But for the most part, our troops' morale was good.
And my second time, my participation was not so much involved in combat as it was in combat support.
We were the MACV and we had so many subordinate units assigned to us
I just went from unit to unit checking on their condition and their morale and whatnot.
The second time I had one sergeant first class, he was an advisor to the 42nd Arvin Regiment.
That particular regiment was one of the sorriest that I'd ever known about.
I mean, they'd walk 30 miles to avoid engaging with the enemy.
Sergeant Wall was sped up with it and wanted out.
He didn't want to go back to an American unit or someplace, but he wanted out of that unit.
And the lieutenant colonel, who was his team commander, didn't appreciate that and wanted to reduce him for insubordination.
So my duty position is sergeant major, and I'm responsible to all who are enlisted personnel.
So I had Sergeant Wall report to us, and I talked to him for a couple hours, and he explained to me his situation.
And I agreed with him wholeheartedly.
So I got with Colonel Miller, who was our zone commander, the position was that of a brigadier general, and I suggested that we pull Sergeant Wall out of the team and reassign him to 2 Corps
somewhere in the G-3 section, G-2 or G-3 section, that he'd be more beneficial back there.
He will be totally ineffective in the 42nd Regiment because he has no respect for them.
I have no respect for them.
You have no respect for them.
We'll send a new NCO up there.
And he agreed with me, so Sergeant Waller was reassigned to 2 Corps Headquarters for General Timothy.

and we put another unit another sergeant in the 42nd regiment but our opinion of the urban troops is they didn't want to fight any more than anybody else did for example we we knew the tunarong valley was infested with the nba and we kept trying to get the vietnamese commander to commit
operations to the Tumarong Valley to engage in an attempt to destroy the enemy.
And they kept coming up with other ideas and whatnot.
They didn't want to go to the Tumarong Valley.
And I don't remember the dates, but I remember Colonel Miller had 45 days left in the country.
And we finally got him to go en masse to the Tumarong Valley.
We took them in by helicopter, dropped them on this mountaintop, and they put up wire and everything.
They were running patrols off this mountaintop.
After the third day, they came under a heavy attack.
And the enemy got all the way up to the wire, got hung up in the wire.
And they even had some hand-to-hand fighting.
So the next day,
The Vietnamese colonel and his entourage, he never went anywhere without half a dozen people with him.
Bodyguard and half his staff.
My colonel and me, we get on a Huey and we go to the mountain top to see what's going on and get some kind of command structure.
We land and we can see the enemy laying all over the place.
But the Arbors did take a heavy toll of casualties on their own.
And the Vietnamese colonel decided he had to withdraw his troops.
So we started calling the Hueys in to withdraw the Arbors.
Well, as the Hueys were coming in, they'd come under intense fire again.
abandoned the use of Hueys and went to Chinooks.
But if they lose a helicopter, it's best to lose one Chinook rather than a couple of Hueys.
Even though we've got a greater amount of Cagulis, they switch from Hueys to Chinooks.
But in the process, they had this prisoner who convinced the Arvin commander that he was going to show them where the
the command base was for the enemy troops.
Well, our chopper was already overloaded because of this entourage that we had to meet the colonel.
So my colonel told me to stay on the mountain until they come back.
And they put that prisoner in that place.
That helicopter didn't get 500 yards from that mountaintop when it was shot down.
Of course, everybody on it was killed.
And so I got on another helicopter and went out with them to come back to base.
But here we got, it took us all that time to get those Vietnamese into that area, knowing that the enemy is there.
We're soldiers.
Our sole function on Earth is to fight when the time comes.
But when the time came, they wanted to get the hell out.
To me, that's cowardice.
And I have no respect for the Vietnamese military from the command structure on down, beginning with the command structure.
In fact, one time, my first time, we were on a patrol operation, and then I got a call from my CO.
He was still back in base camp.
It was just my platoon out there in the boondocks.
And he told me to switch radio frequencies and report to
Brigade headquarters.
I was going to be under their command for a while.
So I switched frequencies and contacted Brigade and they gave me a destination somewhere to the north of us.
And it was a village, a small village.
And he told me to go up to that village and there would be an American colonel that I was to report to and he would give me my instructions.
So, and I was to stay with them until that colonel released me, and then I'd come back to base camp.
So we go up there.
It took us something like seven hours to get there.
And I report to that colonel, and it was getting dark by the time we got there.
And the colonel had told me that we were to augment a police unit to protect this village.
that the night before they came under attack and half the police deserted.
So he introduces me to this commander in this police unit, and this commander told me where to set up my troops.
And boy, they put us in the sorriest position they could think of, where his troops was out here where they could see, mine was out here in the, well, it's not a jungle, but it's,
a wooded area, and you couldn't see your hands in front of your face at night.
And I was supposed to give him any support that he requested.
Well, he passed word over to me that he wanted me to have an artillery fire, H&I, harassing and introductory fire, all night.
And he kept wanting the illumination ramp.
But he wanted the illumination rounds out there in the front where his troops could see out in these open rice paddies where he could see anyhow.
But he didn't know where my troops were so they could see.
Well, I didn't like the idea of firing all this stuff all night long.
I mean, that's just a waste of ammunition.
So every now and then I'd have a firing illumination round.
And every now and then an H-9.
But not all night.
But I'd already known that half of them deserted the night before.
So that kind of had me worried.
They're supposed to be behind us.
We're making a big circle around this village.
I didn't sleep at all that night.
I just kept walking the line.
I wanted to know if they were still back there.
And then I found out that that commander had gotten in his vehicle and gone to the village of Mito.
And that the night of the battle, he'd also been a meantime.
So he was not there when his troops came under fire.
That's probably why they deserted.
And there's another reason why I couldn't trust the Vietnamese.
You don't know if they're going to be there or where their commander's going to be.
That's just two different instances that I know firsthand.
I've heard about a lot of other things.
You can't talk about something second-hand.
You have to know first-hand knowledge.
What did you think about the Vietnamese people?
Was there much contact?
Well, the Vietnamese people were a few that I had direct contact with.
The first time in particular, we run into some civilians.
But every time we run into any civilians, it was old folks.
where they appear to be at.
They age pretty quickly.
They might look like they're 90 years old and want to be 30.
But the ones we'd come in contact with out at Loon Docks was old women and young kids.
The men, they were either drafted in the Army or the Viet Cong was drafted.
The only time we'd ever run into a male
Because he was either ancient or very, very young.
If we come into a village and there was a mid-aged young man, we'd have to be very suspicious of him.
Because he would probably be a VC, or he's a deserter from the Oregon Army.
If he's in his teens or twenties.
For the most part, we'd come into these little villages, and they'd only be, sometimes it'd be one hooch.
There might be a cluster of six or seven hoochies.
Inevitably, the little kids would come up to us and mostly ask them for Salem cigarettes.
Always Salem.
And old Mama Son would come out and fix up a pot of tea.
And all this tea.
And flattened out bananas.
In fact, I ate a banana for a year and didn't know I was eating a banana.
But they were friendly to us.
But I think they were mostly friendly to us because they were afraid of us.
The VC would tell them one thing and we'd try to tell them another thing.
They were totally confused.
They could care less if we were there or not.
They'd rather we weren't.
